I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  Government  of  Bhutan  has  requested  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to 
provide  advisory  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Capacity  Building  for  the  Bhutan  Power 
Corporation (BPC).  A mission visited Bhutan on 25–27 April 2005 to formulate the proposed TA 
and  reach  an  understanding  with  the  Government  on  the  purpose,  scope,  implementation 
arrangements, cost estimates, financing arrangements, and terms of reference for consultants.1 
The TA is included in the Bhutan country strategy and program update (CSPU), 2004–2006. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Bhutan generates significantly more electricity than it consumes.  With a total installed 
capacity of about 457 megawatts (MW)2 and a maximum domestic demand of 112 MW, Bhutan 
is a net power exporter.  The energy sector accounts for about 11% of gross domestic product 
(GDP) and provides the Government with about 45% of its total revenue.  With the production of 
an additional 1020 MW expected in 2006 following the commissioning of the Tala hydropower 
project,  it  is  expected  that  the  energy  sector  will  be  responsible  for  over  60%  of  the 
Government’s revenue by the end of 2007.  Given the importance of the energy sector, the 
Government’s strategy is to continue to give highest priority to developing Bhutan’s hydropower 
potential in order to increase government revenues and provide an important input for economic 
growth and development, with minimal environmental impacts. 
 
3.  The Government is also committed to expanding rural electrification. The Vision 2020 
policy document has a target of 100% electrification by 2020.  Accordingly, under the Ninth 
Five-Year Plan (NFYP), 2002–2007, the Government intends to electrify 15,000 households.  
This will increase the total number of consumers by about 20%,and the percentage of the 
national population with electricity by 8%, to 57%. An even more ambitious program of rural 
electrification is expected in the Tenth Five-Year Plan. 
   
4.  ADB  strongly  supports  the  government’s  strategy  and  has  provided  significant 
assistance to the power sector. Starting in 1998, the Government and ADB agreed to implement 
a series of TA projects to restructure and strengthen the power sector over 8 years.  The TA 
projects have helped to build the institutional capacity of the former Department of Power 
(DOP),  established  a  framework  for  the  power  sector,  and  outlined  a  timetable  for  sector 
reforms.  In 2002, the Government unbundled the Department of Power (DOP) in order to 
improve the efficiency of the sector agencies. Under the current structure, the Department of 
Energy (DOE) serves as the policy-making and planning body for the Government, Bhutan 
Electricity Authority (BEA) is the sector regulator, and BPC is the transmission, distribution, and 
supply  company.  This  reorganization  was  a  significant  step  forward  to  improving  sector 
efficiency and service delivery.   
 
5.  While  significant  steps  have  been  taken,  the  institutions  in  the  energy  sector  will 
continue to need assistance for some time to improve efficiency in planning, operations, and 
management and to develop institutional self-sufficiency. ADB’s draft energy sector road map 
for  Bhutan,  2006–2010,  notes  that  the  following  assistance  will  be  required.  For  DOE,

assistance will be needed for institutional strengthening to enhance its policy and planning 
capacity, especially with regard to renewable energy and establishing the preconditions for 
private sector participation in generation. For BEA, assistance will include ensuring that it is fully 
staffed with the appropriate skills mix, that staff receive ongoing training and experience in order 
to effectively carry out BEA’s mandate, and that BEA receives assistance to review tariff cross-
subsidies to ensure that they are rational and targeted. For BPC, assistance is needed to 
strengthen  investment  and  operations  planning  and  implement  a  management  information 
system (MIS). These will help to ensure BPC’s efficient operations, its long-term sustainability, 
and its capacity to implement sector-type loans.  In 2003, ADB produced a technical assistance 
performance audit report3 (TPAR) which outlined several areas of BPC’s work that needed to be 
addressed,  including:  (i)  the  need  to  establish  sustainable  commercial  and  financial 
arrangements for rural electrification, (ii) upgrading of the computerized accounting system that 
was installed under a previous TA,4 and (iii) optimizing the organizational and operational 
efficiency of BPC.  This TA proposes to assist BPC with all three issues identified in the TPAR. 
 
6.  BPC was corporatized on 1 July 2002 under the Bhutan Companies Act, 2000.  BPC is 
governed by a board of seven directors chaired by the Minister of Trade and Industry. It is 
headed  by  a  managing  director  and  comprises  six  departments:  (i)  customer  services,5 
(ii) development and construction, (iii) transmission, (iv) procurement services, (v) finance and 
accounts, and (iv) human resources.  It is the largest corporation in Bhutan with operations in 19 
dzongkhags (districts) and staffing equal to almost 10% of the total civil service strength.  Given 
the high costs of rural electrification in Bhutan, in the preparatory analysis and design of BPC it 
was found that BPC would find it difficult to maintain the required rates of return on assets to 
ensure its financial viability.  Power tariffs in Bhutan are relatively low.  Although they cover the 
cost of generation, they cannot pay for the high cost of expanding the rural electrification 
network.  Fortunately, system losses are quite low, about 13%.  Either BPC’s financial viability 
would have to be ensured by cash infusions from the Ministry of Finance (MOF) to subsidize the 
expansion and operations of the rural electrification system, or it would have to be given the 
responsibility for power transmission so that the substantial earnings from transmitting power to 
India could help to ensure its financial sustainability.  The first of these options was chosen, but 
BPC’s long-term financial sustainability remains an issue. DOE has proposed several scenarios 
to  the  Ministry  of  Finance,  the  most  significant  of  which  is  that,  given  the  social  and 
development role of rural electrification, the Government would take back the assets needed for 
rural electrification and take responsibility for all future investments for the rural electrification 
expansion. BPC would implement future expansion and manage the assets on an operation and 
management contract.  This model has been successfully used in Singapore and Thailand, 
among others.  
 
7.  BPC has made significant strides towards improving the efficiency of the power sector.  
It has replaced all the meters in urban areas, improved its billing and collection systems, and 
expanded the rural electrification network.  However, it continues to be plagued by a shortage of 
qualified  and  experienced  staff  (like  all  companies  and  government  agencies  in  Bhutan), 
especially  in  senior  management,  financial  planning  and  management,  and  information 
technology.

8.  Given the above issues, BPC requires technical assistance to improve its operational 
efficiency, financial planning and management abilities, and manage its data.  ADB has been 
associated from the beginning (1993–1994) with power sector reforms in Bhutan. The reforms 
initiated with ADB assistance have been rated “very successful”,6 particularly in the major 
restructuring of the former DOP.  It is a measure of this success that the Government has 
restructured the power sector by unbundling DOP to establish DOE, BEA, and BPC.  As the 
energy sector in Bhutan is growing and the Government aims at 100% electricity connectivity 
through  rural  electrification  programs,  there  is  increasing  need  for  an  efficient  delivery 
mechanism. The TA is also in line with the government’s strategy for the sector, ADB’s draft 
energy sector road map for Bhutan and the energy policy, 2000.  This TA is therefore timely and 
critical for preparing the sector for meeting its growing responsibilities.  
 
9.  ADB is the main development partner in power sector restructuring, distribution reforms, 
and rural electrification expansion.  In the NFYP, in addition to the 8,000 households that ADB is 
helping to electrify, about 3,000 rural households will be electrified using assistance from the 
Sustainable Development Secretariat (funded by the Government of the Netherlands) and about 
1,000  using  assistance  from  the  Austrian  Coordination  Bureau.  The  Japan  International 
Cooperation Agency is supporting the preparation of a rural electrification master plan that will 
serve as a road map for future rural electrification projects in the Tenth, Eleventh, and Twelfth 
Five-Year Plans. Japan Bank of International Cooperation has expressed interest in providing 
assistance for rural electrification. The Norwegian Agency for  Development Cooperation is 
providing  assistance  to  DOE  to  strengthen  BEA.    The  Government  of  India  is  providing 
assistance for an Integrated Energy Master Plan with an emphasis on renewable energy.  In 
addition, the Government of India is the primary source of assistance for Bhutan’s hydropower 
potential, financing the Tala hydropower project and transmission lines that will evacuate power 
from Kurichhu and Tala.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The goal of the TA is to improve the overall efficiency of the energy sector.  The TA will 
result in: (i) a financial framework to improve BPC’s financial planning and management and 
address commercial and sustainability issues; (ii) an enterprise resource planning system to 
improve operations efficiency; (iii) a design for a management information system to improve 
planning, management and operational efficiency; and (iv) more knowledgeable and effective 
staff.  The TA framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The TA will have three components.  
 
(i)  Component 1 – Development of a financial management framework.  A 
consultant with expertise in financial management of a utility will work with the 
General Manager, Finance and Accounts.  The consultant will review BPC’s 
corporate  strategic  plan  and  help  to  develop  benchmarks  for  operational 
efficiency, losses, reliability, fund utilization, delivery cost, financial returns, and 
other important aspects of utility performance.  The consultant will review the

4   
financial data and recommend whether additional data is needed to reveal BPC’s 
true financial position. The consultant will then work with staff from the Finance 
and Accounts Department and Information Technology Division to develop an 
integrated financial management system to help BPC in investment planning, 
asset management, and risk assessment and management. The consultant will 
also  investigate  how  planned  and  unplanned  expenditures  mandated  by  the 
Government (mainly those affecting rural electrification) affect BPC’s financial 
viability.  Various financial models to reflect alternative arrangements for the 
expansion and operation of the rural electrification network will be evaluated.  
 
(ii)  Component  2  –  Development  of  an  enterprise  and  materials  resource 
planning  system.    Two  consultants,  a  utility  management  expert  and  an 
enterprise resource planning expert, will work with the General Managers for 
Customer Services and Procurement Services. The consultants will assist staff to 
develop an inventory management and control system that is integrated into the 
Procurement Services Department and operational units. The consultants should 
also  work  with  BPC  staff  to  conduct  an  assessment  of  how  to  set  up  a 
management information system (MIS) for overall enterprise resource planning to 
improve the efficiency of the supply chain management. 
 
(iii)  Component  3  –  Design  of  a  management  information  system.  The 
consultants  will  work  with  the  GM,  Customer  Services  Department.    The 
consultants will carry out a needs assessment with a view to establishing a 
comprehensive management information system to provide adequate coverage 
and  depth  of  data  and  the  information  required  for  all  levels  of  executive 
decision-making.  The management information system will integrate the findings 
and design of components 1 and 2 with BPC’s current computerized billing and 
accounting systems and other components such as administration and human 
resource management.  
 
12.  All the key activities will maximize the transfer of knowledge and experience to the 
counterpart BPC staff.  The consultants will also provide training to enhance the capacity of 
BPC staff.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The total cost of the proposed TA is estimated at $500,000 equivalent, comprising about 
$400,000 in foreign exchange cost and about $100,000 equivalent in local currency cost. ADB 
will provide $400,000 to cover the full foreign exchange cost on a grant basis from ADB’s TA 
funding program.  The Government will contribute the remaining $100,000 equivalent of local 
currency costs in kind.  The cost estimates are in Appendix 2.   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  BPC will be the Executing Agency for the TA. The Managing Director of BPC will provide 
overall direction for the TA and ensure that each component is implemented in a coordinated 
and  timely  manner.    BPC  will  establish  a  counterpart  task  force  comprising  the  general 
managers of the appropriate departments and other relevant staff.  The Managing Director will 
ensure that the general managers are made available and that relevant staff are assigned to the 
working group. BPC will provide office space and administrative support to the consultants.

5
                     
15.  The formation of the task force is essential to the success of the TA. Experience has 
shown that when there is a large TA team, it often operates independently, focusing only on 
outputs rather than working with staff to transfer knowledge and experience.  The task force will 
ensure that BPC staff are involved in the collection, extrapolation, and analysis of data and 
information and with the design and development of models or systems to ensure knowledge 
and experience are transferred.   
 
16.  To maximize the benefits from the TA, BPC will hire two officers in the Finance and 
Administration Department.  One will be a certified public accountant and the other will have a 
Masters of Business Administration in finance.  BPC will also hire two qualified officers in the 
Information Technology Division.  One will be the Senior Information Technology Manager and 
the other will be a System and Network Administrator.  BPC will seek expatriate staff if qualified 
Bhutanese staff are not available. 
 
17.  The  consultants  will  work  closely  with  their  counterparts  to  develop  detailed 
implementation  plans  that  will  serve  as  the  inception  reports  for  each  component.    The 
consultants will prepare a midterm report to document the work that they have done, discuss 
significant issues, if any, and make changes to the implementation schedule, if necessary.  
They will prepare a final report upon completion of their tasks.  It is expected that the final report 
will provide details of implementation and outputs. All reports will be submitted to BPC and ADB 
in draft form for review and comment and the final report will be submitted in electronic and hard 
copies after incorporation of the comments. 
    
18.  The TA will begin in August 2005. It will be carried out over 9 months and will be 
completed  by  31  May  2006.    It  will  require  16  person-months  of  international  consulting 
services.  The outline terms of reference for consulting services are in Appendix 3.  The 
consultants will be selected in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
using biodata and quality- and cost-based selection. The consultants will be expected to spend 
90% of their time in the field. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Bhutan for Capacity Building for the Bhutan Power Corporation, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  A total of 16 person-months of international consulting services will be required for the 
technical assistance (TA).  The consultants will be expected to spend 90% of their time in the 
field. 
 
1.  Financial Management Expert (6.0 person-months) 
2.  The expert will have over 10 years’ experience working in a senior management position 
in a power utility in financial analysis, planning, and management.  The consultant will do the 
following.  
 
(i)   Gather, collate, and interpret technical and financial data, to establish the true 
position  of  the  Bhutan  Power  Corporation  (BPC)  in  terms  of  operational 
efficiency, losses, reliability, fund utilization, delivery cost, financial returns, and 
other important benchmarks of utility performance.  The consultants will use the 
financial management assessment questionnaire developed by ADB to assess 
BPC’s financial situation. 
 
(ii)  Plan investments for both the short and long term (to 2025).  This will include 
establishing clear financial and technical criteria for investments.  The consultant 
will investigate the cost of capital for BPC and possibly establish hurdle rates for 
different categories of investments. 
 
(iii)  Interpret and integrate various financial data, statements, and ratios, establish a 
comprehensive  integrated  financial  model  containing  the  implications  of  the  
information for short- and for long-term planning.  The model will include financial 
projections  (income  statement,  balance  sheet,  etc.),  load  and  revenue 
forecasting, capital budgeting, cash flow management, assessment of the need 
for bridging finance, etc. 
 
(iv)  Work  with  the  management  information  system  (MIS)  expert  to  review  the 
commercial accounting system delivered under ADB TA-29121, to include the 
fixed asset and purchase inventory system (from an accounting perspective) and 
the  accounts  payable  system  and  to  recommend  additional  features  and 
improvements.  The consultant will also help to identify new functions and system 
requirements for financial management, such as budget management systems, 
project accounting systems, daily cashflow implementation, etc.  In addition, the 
consultant will look at internal systems of control and internal audit systems and 
identify whether these need to be strengthened or new ones devised. 
 
(v)  Help establish the cost of delivery of business and cost centers and determine 
transfer prices between relevant units.

(vi)  Conduct risk assessment and management.  The consultant will recommend an 
appropriate capital structure, taking into account the costs of debt, equity, taxes,

(vii)  Advise on treatment of planned and unplanned expenditure as mandated by the 
Government, taking into account social obligations, especially with regard to rural 
electrification  and  conduct  financial  analysis  for  alternative  models  for 
management of rural electrification assets. 
 
(viii)  In addition, the expert would be required to provide inputs for the management 
and the philosophy to be adopted for the financial component of the MIS. 
   
2.  Electric Utility Management Expert (3.5 person-months)  
 
3.  The expert will have at least 10 years’ work experience in a power utility in a senior 
management position.  The expert will work with the other experts, especially the MIS expert, to 
do the following.   
  
(i)  Prepare an asset management plan and a strategic decision making process that 
will help determine decision to run, repair, or replace assets and address other 
strategic decisions such as whether to buy or produce, employ or outsource.   
The consultant will also review asset valuations (especially for old, stranded and 
loss-making assets) and recommend sell-offs and write-offs where necessary. 
 
(ii)  Establish benchmarking and measurement techniques to measure the efficiency 
of various operational units (e.g., transmission, distribution, and procurement) 
including their subunits.  
 
(iii)  Work with the financial expert to study the possibility of setting up of cost and/or 
profit centers and transfer pricing between various business units. 
 
3.  Enterprise Resource Planning Expert (2.5 person-months) 
 
4.  The expert will have at least 10 years’ work experience in a power utility and will do the 
following.  
 
(i)  Develop a materials resource planning system, with special emphasis on proper 
inventory management and control and procurement practices, especially for 
items required for maintenance.  
 
(ii)  Investigate the following, among others:   
  
•  Critical spare parts – assess the most critical stock-keeping units, such as 
transformers, lightening arresters, and cables, so they are in stores at all 
times.  
 
•  Database – advise BPC on how to establish a materials resource planning 
database covering stock-keeping units, vendors, contracts, inspections, etc. 
 
•  Enterprise  resource  planning  –  advise  on  a  supply  chain  management 
package. With about 80% of the budget invested in materials and inventory

and  the  need  for  transactions  with  many  external  agencies  and  user 
departments, BPC needs to be able to track the entire supply chain. 
 
(iii)  Work with the MIS expert to review the purchase and inventory management and 
control system developed under ADB TA-29122 and advise BPC on whether to 
upgrade  the  system  (by  debugging  and  adding  new  requirements  and/or 
functions)  or  develop  a  new  system,  following  a  system  requirement  study, 
including analysis, design, development, training and implementation with live 
data by external IT firms. 
 
4.  Data/Management Information System Expert (4.0 person-months) 
 
5.  The expert will have significant prior experience in setting up an MIS system for a power 
utility and will do the following.  
 
(i)  Conduct  a  needs  assessment  and  establish  a  comprehensive  MIS  that  will 
provide sufficient coverage and depth of information for all levels of executive 
decision making.  The expert will work with all departments to understand their 
needs  in  order  to  design  an  appropriate  MIS.    The  findings  of  these 
recommendations will be presented to BPC in a workshop. The specific systems 
to be delivered are as follows: 
•  Requirement  analysis, system  analysis,  design,  development,  training  and 
implementation of an integrated human resource information management 
system. 
•  Requirement  analysis, system  analysis,  design,  development,  training  and 
implementation  of  an  integrated  customer  and  complaint  management 
system. 
•  Review the energy accounting system developed under TA-2912 and advise 
whether it needs to be upgraded or replaced by a new system.  
•  Any other systems that are found to be necessary.  
 
(ii)  Recommend improvements to the planning and operational efficiency of the MIS 
to BPC. 
 
(iii)  Review the MIS systems available in the market and make a recommendation to 
BPC  on  the  most  appropriate  system.  Provide  specific  and  detailed  cost 
estimates  for  procurement  and  customization.  Present  these  to  BPC  in  a 
workshop. 
 
(iv)  Develop  management  systems,  such  as  computerized  daily  and  monthly 
reporting formats for the MIS. 
 
(v)  Review procurement options of the financial MIS, taking into account the financial 
MIS  systems  already  available  to  current  government-owned  utilities;  the 
availability,  costs  and  benefits  of  these  systems;  and  specific  software 
development needs. Analyze different approaches and recommend an off-the-
shelf system, requiring minor customization. The new financial MIS is anticipated 
to include (but not be limited to) customer billing, cash management, general 
ledger  and  financial  reporting,  payroll,  human  resources,  asset  records,

(vi)  Prepare the technical requirements and a cost estimate for the hardware needed

B.  Reporting Requirements 
6.  The consultants will submit the following reports: (i) an inception report, 2 weeks after 
project start-up; (ii) a midterm report highlighting progress; and (iii) a final report.  Other reports, 
specific to the three components may also be required, e.g. on the financial model or the

7.  All major draft reports will be circulated to BPC and ADB. The consultants will then
